talk.author: did:plc:77coz236u6px44bwz66sr6tq
talk.utter: But the days post infection also need to be considered - not just a blind correlation like these are doing! The CDC itself has put out info on this, but not sure itâ€™s still accessible. Iâ€™ll look.

talk.author: did:plc:rzr3f4cafpsd6rrkroehs24w
talk.utter: The thing is, RATs just aren't very sensitive. I absolutely do not believe that there is sufficient "residual antigen" in someone's airway mucosa for days or weeks on end to show up as positive if it isn't being replenished by live, replicating virus.

talk.author: did:plc:77coz236u6px44bwz66sr6tq
talk.utter: I hate RATs because there were so many false negatives (last year in particular). I had people coming to work sick that I couldnâ€™t do anything about since they tested negative. Thatâ€™s how I first got it ðŸ˜¡ the current variant seems much more RAT sensitive.

talk.author: did:plc:77coz236u6px44bwz66sr6tq
talk.utter: That is not the correct way to use testing. False positives after infection are due to residual pieces of virus and he should not be considered positive. Days after symptom onset/resolution are used. This is a BIG DEAL. Why is this misinformation out there?!

talk.author: did:plc:ivjtepcp6jegdxkxuxav5a3q
talk.utter: I think the confusion might be that you can indeed test positive on a PCR test for weeks to months, but if you are still testing positive on a RAT test...you're still sick.

talk.author: did:plc:77coz236u6px44bwz66sr6tq
talk.utter: I know the difference and I am referring to RATs. PCR false positives are well known and not a point of contention. CDC came out with the â€˜days post end of feverâ€™ rec.. 1.5 years ago?

talk.author: did:plc:77coz236u6px44bwz66sr6tq

talk.author: did:plc:ivjtepcp6jegdxkxuxav5a3q
talk.utter:
Other people might not, though. I think quite a few people still don't.

That rec is for minimizing contagion, not how long you should rest, and I really can't see any guideline that's going to work for an illness that can range from a sniffle to pneumonia.
